title: Imperative Mood: Everyday Instructions
description: Слушайте короткие ситуации и тренируйте повелительное наклонение в простых жизненных диалогах.

tasks.audioText: At home, it is cold outside. The window in the living room is open. Close the window, please.

options.text: Please shut the window.
Please open the window.
Please clean the window glass.
Please look out of the window.

tasks.explanation: The sentence asks someone to close the window. Option 1 says the same; the other options talk about opening, cleaning, or looking out.

tasks.audioText: A tourist asks a man on the street. He explains the way to the city museum. Go straight and then turn left.
tasks.transcript: Go straight and then turn left.

options.text: Stop here and wait.
Walk forward and then take a left turn.
Walk back and then turn right.
Turn right and then go back.

tasks.explanation: The sentence tells you to go forward and then left. Option 2 has the same directions; the other options say stop, go back, or turn right.

tasks.audioText: In a cafe, you order a cup of coffee. The waiter says the drink is very hot. Don't drink it now.

options.text: Drink the coffee very quickly now.
The coffee is safe, drink it now.
Do not drink the coffee at this moment.
Do not order coffee in this cafe.

tasks.explanation: The sentence says you must not drink the coffee now. Option 3 repeats this idea; the other options tell you to drink now or not to order coffee.

tasks.audioText: In a meeting room, everyone sits at the table. The manager wants to start the discussion. Please turn off your phones.

options.text: Please turn on your phones now.
Please check your phones for new messages.
Please give your phones to the manager.
Switch your phones off, please.

tasks.explanation: The sentence asks people to turn their phones off. Option 4 says the same; the other options talk about turning on, checking, or giving phones.

tasks.audioText: You are on a busy city bus. A safety sign is on the door near you. Do not stand near the door.
tasks.transcript: Do not stand near the door.

options.text: Do not stand close to the door.
Please stand near the door.
Please sit on the floor.
Do not sit on the bus.

tasks.explanation: The sentence says you must not stand near the door. Option 1 uses almost the same words; the other options tell you to stand there, sit, or talk about sitting.

tasks.audioText: In a clothes shop, Anna looks at some T-shirts. She wants to see a different size and color. Try this T-shirt in a medium size.
tasks.transcript: Try this T-shirt in a medium size.

options.text: Please put this T-shirt back on the shelf.
Please try this medium T-shirt.
Please try these jeans in a medium size.
Please buy this T-shirt in a large size.

tasks.explanation: The sentence asks Anna to try a medium T-shirt. Option 2 says the same; the other options talk about putting it back, trying jeans, or buying a large size.

tasks.audioText: At the clinic, the doctor listens to your chest. You cough a lot and feel very tired. Take this medicine twice a day.
tasks.transcript: Take this medicine twice a day.

options.text: Use this medicine once a week.
Do not take this medicine at all.
Use this medicine two times every day.
Take this medicine only in the evening.

tasks.explanation: The sentence tells you to take the medicine two times every day. Option 3 has the same meaning; the other options change how often or say not to take it.

tasks.audioText: You cook soup with your friend in the kitchen. The water in the pot starts to boil fast. Turn down the heat a little.
tasks.transcript: Turn down the heat a little.

options.text: Turn off the light in the kitchen.
Add more salt to the soup.
Make the heat very high now.
Make the heat a bit lower.

tasks.explanation: The sentence says to make the heat a little lower. Option 4 means lower the heat; the other options talk about lights, salt, or making the heat high.

tasks.audioText: At the airport, you go through security control. An officer wants to see what is in your bag. Open your bag, please.

options.text: Please open your bag now.
Please close your bag now.
Please give me your passport now.
Please put your bag on the plane.

tasks.explanation: The sentence asks you to open your bag. Option 1 says to open it now; the other options say to close it, give a passport, or put the bag on the plane.

tasks.audioText: In English class, the teacher gives homework for today. She wants you to do some tasks at home. Please finish this exercise at home.
tasks.transcript: Please finish this exercise at home.

options.text: Please read this exercise but do not write.
Do the rest of this exercise at home, please.
Please start this exercise tomorrow in class.
Please finish this exercise now in the classroom.

tasks.explanation: The sentence tells you to finish the exercise at home. Option 2 says to do the rest at home; the other options change the place or time, or only read.

tasks.audioText: You sit in a small restaurant with a friend. The waiter brings soup in a big white plate. Be careful, the plate is very hot.
tasks.transcript: Be careful, the plate is very hot.

options.text: Do not worry, the plate is cold.
Please make the plate very hot.
Pay attention, the dish is really hot.
The plate is empty and not hot.

tasks.explanation: The sentence warns you that the plate is very hot. Option 3 has the same warning; the other options say it is cold, empty, or tell you to heat it.

tasks.audioText: At the bank, a worker gives you a form. You must write your name before you get money. Please sign your name on this line.
tasks.transcript: Please sign your name on this line.

options.text: Write your address on this line, please.
Do not write anything on this line.
Please sign your name on every page.
Write your name here, please.

tasks.explanation: The sentence asks you to sign, or write, your name on one line. Option 4 matches this; the other options talk about an address, nothing, or every page.

tasks.audioText: In the gym, you try a new exercise. The trainer wants you to listen to your body. Stop if you feel any pain.
tasks.transcript: Stop if you feel any pain.

options.text: Do not continue when you feel pain.
Continue even when you feel pain.
Start when you feel pain in your legs.
Stop if you feel hungry or thirsty.

tasks.explanation: The sentence tells you to stop when you feel pain. Option 1 says not to continue if you feel pain; the other options say to continue, to start, or stop for another reason.

tasks.audioText: At the post office, you send an important letter. The worker gives you a receipt with your name. Please check your name before you leave.
tasks.transcript: Please check your name before you leave.

options.text: Please write your name after you leave.
Please make sure your name is correct.
Please check your address before you leave.
Please check your passport number before you go.

tasks.explanation: The sentence asks you to check your name before you go. Option 2 says to make sure your name is correct; the other options talk about address, time, or passport number.

tasks.audioText: You sit in a taxi going to your hotel. The driver does not know the exact entrance. Tell me when I should stop.
tasks.transcript: Tell me when I should stop.

options.text: Please stop the taxi right now.
Please tell me where you live.
Please say when I need to stop.
Please tell me how much it costs.

tasks.explanation: The sentence asks the passenger to say when the driver must stop. Option 3 has the same meaning; the other options ask to stop now, give an address, or talk about the price.

short_description: Тренируйте понимание повелительных предложений в повседневных ситуациях на слух.
